channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: ACLU warns hundreds of Venezuelans face immediate deportation under Alien Enemies Act despite Supreme Court decision
item.description: A recent Supreme Court ruling instructed the Trump administration to give migrants being deported under the Alien Enemies Act due process. The ACLU says a group of migrants in Texas have been given less than 24 hours.
item.content:encoded: A recent Supreme Court ruling instructed the Trump administration to give migrants being deported under the Alien Enemies Act due process. The ACLU says a group of migrants in Texas have been given less than 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Garsd

item.title: Head Start advocates brace for possibility of Trump eliminating funding
item.description: A Trump administration document, cited by news reports, proposes eliminating funding for Head Start, which is dedicated to early child care services. An advocate says the move would be "catastrophic."
item.content:encoded:
A Trump administration document, cited by news reports, proposes eliminating funding for Head Start, which is dedicated to early child care services. An advocate says the move would be "catastrophic."

(Image credit: Rebecca Blackwell)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: Thousands of federal workers would be easier to fire under Trump rule change
item.description: The Trump administration is moving forward with efforts to make it easier to fire some federal workers, as part of its push to both shrink the federal government and exert more control over it.
item.content:encoded:
The Trump administration is moving forward with efforts to make it easier to fire some federal workers, as part of its push to both shrink the federal government and exert more control over it.

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan)
item.dc:creator: Shannon Bond

item.title: History shows revoking Harvard's tax status won't be easy â€” or fast
item.description: A presidential effort to revoke Harvard University's tax-exempt status could run up against a number of challenges, including violating federal law.
item.content:encoded:
A presidential effort to revoke Harvard University's tax-exempt status could run up against a number of challenges, including violating federal law.

(Image credit: Bettmann Archive)
item.dc:creator: Jonaki Mehta

item.title: 'Lab Leak,' a flashy page on the virus' origins, replaces government COVID sites
item.description: The new page emphatically promotes a theory that many scientists question. Meanwhile, basic information about COVID testing and vaccines has disappeared.
item.content:encoded:
The new page emphatically promotes a theory that many scientists question. Meanwhile, basic information about COVID testing and vaccines has disappeared.

(Image credit: Whitehouse.gov/Screenshot by NPR)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: 30 years later, Oklahoma City bombing survivor recalls vow to change her life while trapped
item.description: Amy Downs was buried in 10 feet of rubble after the Oklahoma City bombing 30 years ago. While trapped, she vowed to change her life, but it was long journey.
item.content:encoded:
Amy Downs was buried in 10 feet of rubble after the Oklahoma City bombing 30 years ago. While trapped, she vowed to change her life, but it was long journey.

(Image credit: LM Otero)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Morales

item.title: Nearly 300 scientists apply for French academic program amid Trump cuts in U.S.
item.description: Nearly 300 U.S.-based researchers have applied to one program that promises "scientific refugee status" for those fleeing Trump's academic funding rollbacks.
item.content:encoded:
Nearly 300 U.S.-based researchers have applied to one program that promises "scientific refugee status" for those fleeing Trump's academic funding rollbacks.

(Image credit: Robyn Beck)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: VA officials acknowledge the need for privacy for telehealth therapy
item.description: The VA looks like it is changing course on a plan that would have threatened the privacy of veterans receiving mental health care via telehealth, according to documents obtained by NPR.
item.content:encoded:
The VA looks like it is changing course on a plan that would have threatened the privacy of veterans receiving mental health care via telehealth, according to documents obtained by NPR.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: Journalist Joy-Ann Reid revisits the legacy and marriage of Medgar and Myrlie Evers
item.description: Reid's book, Medgar and Myrlie, tells the stories of the civil rights leader from Mississippi and his wife, who became an activist after Medgar's 1963 assassination. Originally broadcast Feb. 7, 2024.
item.content:encoded: Reid's book, Medgar and Myrlie, tells the stories of the civil rights leader from Mississippi and his wife, who became an activist after Medgar's 1963 assassination. Originally broadcast Feb. 7, 2024.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: How FDA cuts could make the food and drug supply less safe
item.description: While Food and Drug Administration inspectors who make sure food and drugs meet quality standards were spared in recent cuts, key support staffers were dismissed.
item.content:encoded:
While Food and Drug Administration inspectors who make sure food and drugs meet quality standards were spared in recent cuts, key support staffers were dismissed.

(Image credit: Stefani Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Sydney Lupkin
